How do you address the following counterpoint?:
Very many modern discoveries in physics are dependent on basic concepts that were discovered hundreds of years ago. How are you supposed to teach a student what the strong and weak nuclear forces are if they do not have a fundamental understanding of what a force is and how it affects an object (not where it comes from, but what it DOES)? This fundamental understanding comes directly from newtonian physics. How do you teach a student not to fall for internet junk science about overunity machines if they don't have the basic understanding of work and the conservation of energy that comes from the work of James Prescott Joule, Lord Kelvin, and other 19th century scientists? How can they grasp diodes and transistors if they do not understand what a potential difference is in the simpler context of the work of Alessandro Volta and Georg Ohm?
The fact is that teaching these things effectively takes time. High school physics teachers have, in some cases, just 9 months to teach as much physics as we possibly can.
I am not arguing that these newer topics should not be taught-- in fact, I strongly believe that they should be, and I do teach many of them including the photoelectric effect, deBroglie wavelengths, nuclear decay and radiation, atomic spectroscopy, and some special relativity. But to tell teachers not to bother teaching Newton's law of universal gravitation "because it's just an approximation" ignores the larger pedagogical point. I want my students to learn Newton's theory in October and know it well so that when they hear that black holes attract massless photons in April, they say "But wait!". These are the most beautiful moments in teaching physics, when students recognize exactly what is wrong about these old theories and speak out. That is how science is done in real life. They need to learn to question accepted scientific theories based on contrary evidence.
You make an analogy to history-- but history is the same way. How can a student possibly understand the civil rights movement of the 20th century without the context of the slave trade in the 17th and 18th centuries and the Civil War in the 19th?

Lastly, from a more practical perspective, I understand the desire for students to know "how it really is", but for 98% of the population, the approximations of Newton and Galileo are still incredibly useful for describing force and motion on a macroscopic, everyday life scale, and far easier to teach and learn, both conceptually and mathematically. As long as they are made to understand that these are only approximations, we owe it to students to continue to teach them in great detail. No physics teacher worth his/her salt would earnestly tell students that
Newton's ideas are the most modern picture of gravity, or teach galilean kinematics without emphasizing that things get substantially more complicated when the earth's curvature is introduced. To oversimplify by saying that I am "lying" to my students by making them learn a theory that is no longer considered the best model is a bit insulting to me and to good physics teachers everywhere. And the implication that the president or secretary of education would have the ability to rectify this perceived problem just by introducing curriculum changes from the outside is very misguided.

One very important thing to note or (impose as briefly mentioned in the video) is the actual mathematics behind Physics. Realistically, anyone could somewhat easily understand any concept in physics. String Theory for example, is not hard to understand. What makes physics a difficult subject is understand the applications of fundamental concepts and the mathematics they entail. For instance, anyone could describe what would happen if you released a yo-yo from rest, but understanding the forces and torques that may act on it and being to understand the math involved in such is more challenging. Also, the whole idea of formulas is overly contrived when first taught in high school, for example. We learn about Newton's Second Law, and assume that a scientist calculates force by simply multiplying mass and acceleration. When in reality, most people are unaware as to how Newton even came up with the formula (by realizing velocity as a derivative of time could be expressed as acceleration, and also leading him to write F=dP/dt, given P is translational momentum) Not only this, but for example what this formula have lead us to create, such as the equation which we can use to describe harmonic oscillators (x''+(b/m)x'+(k/m)x=0, [I substituted for gamma and omega]). And this is just kinematics. There is so much to Physics that it is truly astounding to try and comprehend. That's also why most people who believe they know physics really know almost nothing about it. Understanding concepts isn't understanding physics. Knowing how they apply and what they entail and being able to work with them from a mathematical standpoint is. That's really why it's not possible to learn any meaningful physics until college, when you can do actual research and when you have to do actual situation based problem solving and develop unique insight for each problem. It's not something you can just read about or watch videos for: you have to actually practice it.

The degree to which light is bent depends on 1) the strength of the gravitational field and 2) the angle at which the light is passing/leaving it. If the light is traveling out radially from the center of the field it won't be bent at all. But even if it's passing by the source of the field such that they are at right angles, if the strength of the field (which depends on the mass and decreases as the square of distance from the center of mass) is too low it won't ever get turned 180° around.
